summary: Clemard Joseph Charles was a Haitian banker and businessman who was a confidant of President Duvalier. He was of interest to the CIA and State Department, with assessments of his character and business dealings being conducted. He was also considered as a potential political figure and asset. Later, he became a political prisoner allegedly involved in anti-government plotting. The documents detail his financial situation, health issues during imprisonment, and attempts to secure his release or medical treatment. The timeline spans from 1963 to 1974, showing a shift from being a person of interest and potential asset to being imprisoned for plotting against the government.
significance: The documents suggest that Clemard Joseph Charles was a person of interest to the CIA and State Department due to his connections to President Duvalier and his potential as a political figure in Haiti. The documents do not directly connect Clemard Joseph Charles to the JFK assassination. His significance lies in the context of US foreign policy and intelligence gathering in Haiti during the 1960s and 1970s.
